data.title: Possible bug where method is not invoked
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/7c1c21c15870d56b1bbc8dcccda9cb2f56f428df/src/vs/base/parts/quickopen/browser/quickOpenWidget.ts#L421


The `if` check will always return true because the method is not invoked.

data.title: API and extension host work for multi root
data.body: This is an umbrella item that track changes that are required for making the extension host and API multi-root aware.

data.title: Improvement PowerShell ISE theme
data.body:
Due to the editor.lineHighlightBackground setting in the PowerShell ISE theme you cannot see the dashes when interactively typing. Same color for dashes as line highlight background.

Please change the setting for the ISE Theme so you can see the dash when interactively typing to:
"colors": {
		"activityBar.background": "#E1ECF9",
		"activityBar.foreground": "#A9A9A9",
		"activityBarBadge.background": "#A9A9A9",
		"editor.lineHighlightBackground": "#add8e6",
		"editor.selectionBackground": "#94c6f7",
		"statusBar.background": "#999999",
		"statusBar.debuggingBackground": "#FF4500",
		"statusBar.noFolderBackground": "#999999",
		"terminal.background": "#012456",
		"terminal.foreground": "#F5F5F5"
	}
Changed editor.lineHighlightBackground setting from #94c6f7 to #add8e6
/Stefan

data.title: >git responds "No commands matching" after upgrade to 1.13.0
data.body:
After updating to 1.13.0, git support totally disappeared.

Entering, >git responds "No commands matching"

Git was working prior to the upgrade without any issues for several months now.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)

data.title: Find in Files doesnâ€™t live-update symlinked files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

```
mkdir foo
cd foo
echo hello > a
ln -s a sym
code .
```

Then go into Find in Files (Shift-Cmd-F) and search for `hello`. Both `a` and `sym` appear. If I change one file, the other one is still displayed in the original version in the search panel, unless Refresh is pressed.

data.title: Show loaded scripts in a custom explorer section
data.body:
Today loaded scripts can be accessed via the "Open Loaded Script" action which uses a QuickPick UI.

With the new custom explorer support it is possible to show the loaded scripts in the VS Code explorer.

Challenge: since the QuickPick UI is modal it works well in face of concurrent debug sessions and does not need any events from the DAP.

Whereas a custom explorer is non modal and must be updated whenever scripts are loaded/unloaded and when switching between debug sessions.

data.title: js intellisense issues about the custom export module.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

**Environments:**

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Win 10 Pro, 1703 (Build 15063.332)

**Extensions:**
- Beautify 1.1.1
- C/C++ 0.11.4
- C# 1.10.0
- ESLint 1.2.11
- vetur 0.7.0
- vscode-icons 7.9.0
- webpack 2.0.0
- XML Tools 1.8.0

**Issues:**

The intellisense doesn't work when I import a constructor, but after I change the `module.exports` to an object, it seems right.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Create a file named 'mod.js', write these lines.
```javascript
function Test(name) {
  this.name = name;
}
Test.prototype.log = function (msg) {};
module.exports = Test;
```
2. Create another file named 'test.js'.
```javascript
const Test = require('./mod');
let a = new Test('test');
a.    // <- here, the intellisense cannot list the 'name' and 'log'
```
3. Then change the files.

'mod.js'
```diff
-module.exports = Test;
+module.exports = { Test };
```
'test.js'
```diff
-let a = new Test('test');
+let a = new Test.Test('test');
a.    // now the intellisense seems good.
```

**Screen record**

![vsc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/980449/27034248-4fd014a2-4faf-11e7-8d69-c92400140366.gif)

data.title: Paste via terminal.integrated.rightClickCopyPaste doesn't work anymore in the integrated terminal
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.14.0-insider 1cc8f3...
- OS Version: Windows 64 bit (insider 16215)
- cmd.exe used for the integrated terminal

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open an existing file and select + copy some text
2. open the built in terminal & right click in it

What happens?
Nothing happens: nothing is pasted. And the clipboard seems to be empty

What should happen?
Text should be pasted and kept in the clipboard.

Note: selecting & copying some text inside the terminal div and then pasting it inside the terminal seems to work. But if it's copied outside of the terminal div, it doesn't work.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open the diff view for any file from the Source Control panel
2. click the Open File button at the top-right corner of vscode
3. make an edit
4. save the file

What I saw: the dot indicator remained .. like a dot.
Expected: the dot indicator should have become the cross icon

data.title: Task runner in terminal forgets environment?
data.body:
When I have a task runner which executes a batch file (to set up the visual studio dev environment) it doesn't remember the environment for next time, even though it reuses the terminal?

Is there a way to do this? Setting the environment tasks a few seconds so I'd like to only need to do it once if the terminal can be reused.

data.title: Search in files + multiline regex -> wrong selection
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: windows 10  (1703 build 15063.332)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create multiple files with this content:
```xml
  <ItemGroup>
    <Reference Include="SomeLib">
      <Name>SomeLib</Name>
      <HintPath>..\_output\Client\$(Configuration)\SomeLib.dll</HintPath>
      <Private>False</Private>
    </Reference>
  <ItemGroup>
```
2. try search for this regex:
```js
/">\n\s*<Name>.*\n\s*<HintPath>.*\n\s*<Private>.*\n\s*</Reference>/
```

3. a) when searching in single file editor correctly highlights result (in between | chars):
```xml
  <ItemGroup>
    <Reference Include="SomeLib|">
      <Name>SomeLib</Name>
      <HintPath>..\_output\Client\$(Configuration)\SomeLib.dll</HintPath>
      <Private>False</Private>
    </Reference>|
  <ItemGroup>
```
3. b) when searching globaly editor incorrectly highlights wrong characters (again in between | chars):
```xml
  <ItemGroup>
    <Reference I|nclude="SomeLib|">
      <Name>SomeLib</Name>
      <HintPath>..\_output\Client\$(Configuration)\SomeLib.dll</HintPath>
      <Private>False</Private>
    </Reference>
  <ItemGroup>
```

looks line 'global' search dont like multiline regex  - respective it highlighs from correct start char but to invalid end char (end char on wrtong line)

```xml
                 invalid end position: (line: 2, char: 14) - wrong line
1: <ItemGroup>   â†“               â†“ correct start position (line: 2, char: 29)
2:   <Reference I|nclude="SomeLib|">
3:     <Name>Some Lib</Name>
4:     <HintPath> ..\_output\Client\$(Configuration)\SomeLib.dll</HintPath>
5:     <Private>F alse</Private>
6:   </Reference>| 
7: <ItemGroup>   â†‘ correct end position (line: 6, char: 14)
```

---

**expected result:** global search highlights same way as local one - at least in 'file window' (in search results 'tree' it cound show first line followed by tree dots if multiline output isnt possible here)

data.title: Integrated Terminal limited to 80 characters upon first start and first instance
data.body:
**Basic info:**
- VSCode Version: **1.13.0**
- OS Version: **Windows 10 x64 1703 15063.332**
- Monitor resolution: **2560x1440**, VSCode **maximized**

**profile.ps1:**
```
$env:LC_ALL='C.UTF-8'
Import-Module posh-git
```

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open **VSCode** (**PowerShell** is configured as internal terminal)
2. ``Ctrl + ` `` to open the terminal
3. Observe that the terminal is wrapped after **80 characters**

**Additional notes:**

If the first instance of the terminal is closed and then another opened, the problem is gone. This happens only for the **first** instance after starting VSCode.

**Screenshot:**
![vscode_internal_terminal_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16443718/27031851-3fe6f516-4f72-11e7-956f-d486a6a1251a.png)

data.title: File minimap is too narrow
data.body:
It's very good that you have enabled the file minimap by default. I mean a small preview of the file on the right side that allows to jump to any place in the file.

But problem is in current implementation of it. I have few files with **3k+ lines** and this preview becomes very **tiny** and unreadable. In the *Sublime Text* they solved it in a different way - you see the same width of this minimap sidebar, but can scroll on it by dragging mouse over it. It allows me to see the readable text and at the same time scroll to the middle or the end of the file very quickly *(not by one click, but by click and drag mouse that is more natural as for me)*.

If you will have any questions of help - let me know.
Anton

data.title: Add Project Manager extension to VS Code
data.body:
I think that Projects ideology should be in a heart of the VS Code. The main reason for it it that we can have a dedicated folder for each project where we can save project settings (including workspace settings), cache files (for example for file tree to make Go To File super fast and save cache between VS Code reloads), to save cache of external plugins (like such as Python, that saves and uses cache for Go To Symbol In workspace).

Please discuss this decision again in your core team. Because I see that it should be implemented, and all what you need is to take the already existing extension and inject it into the native VS Code build.

Thank you for improvements.
Anton

data.title: Merge conflicts do not detect diff3 conflict style
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set git conflict style to `diff3`. In `~/.gitconfig`:
```
[merge]
    conflictstyle = diff3
```

2. This results in merge conflict format as shown below. You can copy paste this into a blank tab:

```
<<<<<<< Updated upstream
foo
||||||| merged common ancestors
bar
=======
baz
>>>>>>> Stashed changes
```

3. Screenshot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19387055/27029770-69e757c0-4f72-11e7-8d0c-611294d54918.png)

4. If you click "Accept Current Change", the "merged common ancestors" remains:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19387055/27029801-837de2c6-4f72-11e7-8dc8-67135067c17f.png)

Some other notes:

* "Accept Incoming Change" works as expected.
* "Accept Both Changes" results in the following:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19387055/27029951-1c8aa2f6-4f73-11e7-934e-97fbb5c27831.png)

* "Compare Changes" fails with error if not in git repository, or something like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19387055/27030110-abbd2b2e-4f73-11e7-87ed-4973765a4524.png)

(Note the trailing "merged common ancestors" on the left side)

data.title: Diff editor always opens in first editor group
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. have multiple groups
2. select second or third group
3. click on the diff

=> diff always opens in column 1
=> it should open in the active column

This looks like a regression compared to how it used to work in 1.12

data.title: Insert line above indents incorrectly when there is a blank line above it
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: OS X Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

When there is a blank line above, `Insert line above` does not indent correctly. For example:

```
  someDummyCode()

  someOtherCode() // cursor is on this line
```

When I'm on the `someOtherCode` line and invoke `Insert line above`, this is what happens:

```
  someDummyCode()
cursorPutHere() // cursor on this line
  someOtherCode()
```

Whereas I would expect the cursor to be placed at the same indent level as the line I was on.

Not that if there is not a blank line above, the cursor is correctly placed at the right indentation.

I recorded a quick video of this in action: http://recordit.co/4AZFBGje8g

And there is also another GIF in the original issue that was reported on the VSCode-Vim repo: https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1790.

The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.title: Add "always_show_minimap_viewport" option to always highlight visible area
data.body:
Sublime Text knows the `always_show_minimap_viewport` setting for the minimap:

*If `true`, shows a rectangle on the minimap highlighting the fileâ€™s visible area. If `false`, only shows the rectangle when you hover the cursor over the minimap.* 
(Source: [http://docs.sublimetext.info/en/latest/reference/settings.html](http://docs.sublimetext.info/en/latest/reference/settings.html))

![screen_shot_2017-06-12_at_10_58_29](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2169489/27026947-dca0eb4a-4f5f-11e7-86ea-6a457514e433.png)

I did not find an option enable this behavior in Code, I assume it is not there. I suggest implementing this. It helps a lot when navigating the file. Personally I see no benefit in the default behavior of only showing it on mouse-over since this actively reduces the usefulness of the minimap.

data.title: VS Code opens a new window even if window.openFilesInNewWindow is set to off
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro, version 1703, build 15063.296

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file
2. Wait ~2 hours
3. When opening another file, a new instance is created, even if there is a VS Code window already launched

Note: if I close all instances, and open the files again, they are opened in the same window (as new tabs) as they should be, so this bug reproduces only after some time passes.
